description: From Middle English gap, gappe, from Old Norse gap (“an empty space, gap, chasm”), from gapa (“to gape, scream”), from Proto-Germanic *gapōną, from Proto-Indo-European *ǵʰeh₂- (“to open wide, gape”). Related to Danish gab (“an expanse, space, gap”), Old English ġeap (“open space, expanse”); compare English gape.

entries.meaning: An opening in anything made by breaking or parting.
examples: He made a gap in the fence by kicking at a weak spot.

entries.meaning: An opening allowing passage or entrance.
examples: We can slip through that gap between the buildings.

entries.meaning: An opening that implies a breach or defect.
examples: There is a gap between the roof and the gutter.
I have a gap in my schedule next Tuesday.

entries.meaning: A hiatus, a pause in something which is otherwise continuous.
examples: You must wait for a gap in the traffic before crossing the road.

entries.meaning: A vacancy, deficit, absence, or lack.
examples: Their departure has left a gap in the workforce.
Find words to fill the gaps in an incomplete sentence.
She has a gap in her teeth. (see also gap-toothed)
The exploring party went through the high gap in the mountains.

entries.meaning: (Sussex) A sheltered area of coast between two cliffs (mostly restricted to place names).
examples: At Birling Gap we can stop and go have a picnic on the beach.

entries.meaning: (Australia, for a medical or pharmacy item) The shortfall between the amount the medical insurer will pay to the service provider and the scheduled fee for the item.
examples: Under bulk billing the patient does not pay a gap, and the medical practitioner receives 85% of the scheduled fee.

entries.meaning: (Australia) (usually written as "the gap") The disparity between the indigenous and non-indigenous communities with regard to life expectancy, education, health, etc.
(genetics) An unsequenced region in a sequence alignment.

verbs.description: gap (third-person singular simple present gaps, present participle gapping, simple past and past participle gapped)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To notch, as a sword or knife.
(transitive) To make an opening in; to breach.
(transitive) To check the size of a gap.
examples: I gapped all the spark plugs in my car, but then realized I had used the wrong manual and had made them too small.

entries.meaning: Alternative form of gup (elected head of a gewog in Bhutan)
